topic.title: World Wide Web Consortium abandons consensus, standardizes DRM with 58.4% support, EFF resigns
topic.body:
This is a bad day for the W3C: it's the day it publishes a standard
designed to control, rather than empower, web users. That standard that
was explicitly published without any protections -- even the most minimal compromise was rejected without discussion, an intransigence that the W3C leadership tacitly approved.
 It's the day that the W3C changed its process to reward stonewalling
over compromise, provided those doing the stonewalling are the biggest
corporations in the consortium. EFF no longer believes that the W3C process is suited to defending the
open web. We have resigned from the Consortium, effective today. ... 

https://boingboing.net/2017/09/18/antifeatures-for-all.html

[Four Horsemen of the Infocalypse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Horsemen_of_the_Infocalypse): terrorists, pedophiles, drug dealers, and money launderers

How to get what you want in 4 easy stages:

* Have a target "thing" you wish to stop, yet lack any moral, or practical reasons for doing so?
* Pick a fear common to lots of people, something that will evoke a gut reaction: terrorists, pedophiles, serial killers.
* Scream loudly to the media that "thing" is being used by perpetrators. (Don't worry if this is true, or common to all other things, or less common with "thing" than with other long established systems—payphones, paper mail, private hotel rooms, lack of bugs in all houses etc.)
* Say that the only way to stop perpetrators is to close down "thing", or to regulate it to death, or to have laws forcing en-mass tapability of all private communications on "thing". Don't worry if communicating on "thing" is a constitutionally protected right, if you have done a good job in choosing and publicising the horsemen in 2, no one will notice, they will be too busy clamoring for you to save them from the supposed evils.

2_1BiouZaoK2zKaqSihxi7LudLqix6ynXYtj.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_332_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh):  Personally, I can't wait to have ipv6 and dht support so that cjdns can be used. Solving this issue altogether. [...]

I recently looked into cjdns, but it lacks mixing, so it's pretty much [useless for anonymity](https://www.reddit.com/r/cjdns/comments/55rtdn/anonymity_in_cjdns/). I2P support might be interesting, and I'd be curious if it's possible to run Tor/I2P inside of a mesh/cjdns protocol if it doesn't have access to the regular internet.

Your ISP can detect Tor traffic, but they don't know what it is. [Here's an example of what your ISP sees](https://www.rsreese.com/detecting-tor-traffic-with-bro-network-traffic-analyzer/).

The NSA thinks "[Tor stinks](https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/oct/04/tor-stinks-nsa-presentation-document)", but they have upped their game over the years and added [some sibyl nodes](https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/wiki/doc/badRelays). I think it's safe to say they can probably gain access to some of the traffic, being they are a global passive adversary, but they may not be able to watch the entire network yet, just chunks under their control. The Tor project used to maintain a list of rogue exit nodes, but they no longer do. Also their new board of directors thinks it's ok to shame "[nazis](https://blog.torproject.org/blog/tor-project-defends-human-rights-racists-oppose)", so I wouldn't be surprised if they try and implement some form of censorship if they continue along that path.

> Around 1980, when the news media took notice of hackers, they fixated on one narrow aspect of real hacking: the security breaking which some hackers occasionally did. They ignored all the rest of hacking, and took the term to mean breaking security, no more and no less. The media have since spread that definition, disregarding our attempts to correct them. As a result, most people have a mistaken idea of what we hackers actually do and what we think.

> You can help correct the misunderstanding simply by making a distinction between security breaking and hacking—by using the term "cracking" for security breaking. The people who do it are "crackers". Some of them may also be hackers, just as some of them may be chess players or golfers; most of them are not.  ~ [Stallman](https://stallman.org/articles/on-hacking.html)
